Well they can estimate the weight by measuring your belly, plus ultrasounds can be a couple pounds off so it's not even accurate.  Kinda pointless. So many women get induced because they're told they have a "big" baby due to ultrasounds and the baby comes out being 6 ot 7 pounds.

I had an ultrasound at 34 weeks with my first because I'd had marginal placenta previa at my 20 week scan and they wanted to make sure the placenta had moved up and out of the way of my cervix. Otherwise I wouldn't have gotten another one. Position and approximate size can be determined by palpation and abdominal measurement by any reasonably competent midwife or obstetrician - an ultrasound isn't necessary by any means without high risk indicators.
